description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the Greater Flamingo.
title: All About the Greater Flamingo

slides.title: Introduction to the Greater Flamingo
slides.content: The Greater Flamingo (Phoenicopterus roseus) is the largest and most widespread species of flamingo. Famous for its distinctive pink coloration and one-legged stance, it's found across Africa, Asia, and southern Europe in large colonies.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: They stand 3.9-4.7 feet tall and weigh 4.4-9.9 pounds, with the longest neck and legs relative to body size of any bird.
Their pink coloration comes from pigments in their diet, and they have distinctive downward-bending bills for filter feeding.

slides.title: Feeding and Filter Mechanism
content: Flamingos feed by holding their bills upside down in water and using their tongues to pump water through lamellae that filter out small organisms.
They primarily eat algae, crustaceans, and mollusks, consuming 4-5 pounds of food per day to maintain their pink coloration.

slides.title: Social Behavior and Breeding
content: Greater Flamingos are highly social, living in large colonies that can number in the hundreds of thousands.
They perform elaborate synchronized courtship dances and build mud nests in shallow water where both parents incubate the eggs.

slides.title: Conservation and Adaptations
content: Flamingos can drink both fresh and saltwater, excreting excess salt through glands near their eyes.
While not currently endangered, they face threats from habitat loss, pollution, and human disturbance of breeding colonies.
